context: This aspect of the post-hurricane environment was addressed using the Mann–Kendall trend test (Hollander and Wolfe, 1999). The test was applied at the 5% significance level to the observed weekly medians for each area. Only seven statistically significant trends were found. Plots of the observed median values are illustrated in Figs. 4 a through 4f for benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, m,p-xylene, α-pinene, and carbon tetrachloride, respectively. Although the trend is not statistically significant, relatively higher concentrations of the benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylenes (BTEX) compounds in Area 1 and Area 2 during periods 1–3 probably reflect the impact of nearby operation of heavy machinery and diesel vehicles for clean-up activities during the early sampling periods, and the tapering off of these activities after the hurricane. The increasing trend of α-pinene in Area 4 may indicate the recovery of normal vegetative growth in this outlying, less-urbanized area. Carbon tetrachloride is a background pollutant, and as expected, the concentrations were relatively constant across the sampling areas throughout the sampling project.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, ethylbenzene and 4-xylene are both mentioned as part of the BTEX (benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylenes) group of volatile organic compounds. The observed concentrations of these compounds were analyzed in relation to environmental factors following a hurricane. However, there is no detailed discussion of their specific interactions or relationships beyond their classification as related pollutants influenced by similar environmental conditions.
